intro: Gomphia grandifolia, commonly known as the giant horsetail, is a perennial plant belonging to the Equisetaceae family. It is characterized by its tall, jointed stems and whorls of narrow, needle-like leaves. The plant produces spore-bearing structures called strobili at the top of its stem, which are typically green and cylindrical in shape. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Gomphia grandifolia is an ancient plant species with a long evolutionary history, dating back to the Paleozoic era.
